Block-transitive algebraic geometry codes attaining the Tsfasman-Vladut-Zink bound

María Chara, Ricardo Podestá, Ricardo Toledano María Chara – Departamento de Matemática, FIQ-UNL-CONICET, FICH (3000) Santa Fe, Argentina.
E-mail: mchara@santafe-conicet.gov.ar Ricardo Podestá – FaMAF – CIEM (CONICET), Universidad Nacional de Córdoba, (5000) Córdoba, Argentina. E-mail: podesta@famaf.unc.edu.ar Ricardo Toledano – Departamento de Matemática, Facultad de Ingeniería Química, UNL, (3000) Santa Fe, Argentina. E-mail: ridatole@gmail.com
Abstract.

We study the asymptotic behaviour of a family of algebraic geometry codes, which we call block-transitive, that generalizes the classes of transitive and quasi-transitive codes. We prove, by using towers of algebraic function fields, that there are sequences of codes in this family attaining the Tsfasman-Vladut-Zink bound over finite fields of square cardinality. We give the exact length of these codes as well as explicit lower bounds for their parameters.

Key words and phrases:
AG-codes, algebraic function fields, asymptotic goodness, towers.
2010 Mathematics Subject Classification. Primary 94B05; Secondary 11R58, 14H05, 11G20.
Partially supported by CONICET, FONCyT, UNL CAI+D 2014, SECyT-UNC, CSIC

1. Introduction

Let 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} denote a finite field with q𝑞q elements. In 1982, Tsfasman, Vladut and Zink proved, in their remarkable paper [18], that there are sequences of linear codes over 𝔽p2subscript𝔽superscript𝑝2\mathbb{F}_{p^{2}}, p𝑝p a prime number, whose transmission rates satisfy what is known today as the Tsfasman-Vladut-Zink bound. For finite fields of square cardinality bigger than 49, this bound is above the well known Gilbert-Varshamov bound in some interval and thus the work [18] showed, for the first time, the existence of a sequence of linear codes beating the Gilbert-Varshamov bound for infinitely many finite fields. This important result was achieved by considering algebraic geometry codes associated to towers of modular curves over 𝔽p2subscript𝔽superscript𝑝2\mathbb{F}_{p^{2}}. However, as of today, little is known about the structure of these codes besides linearity and the more we know about structural properties of a family of codes the better because they can be very helpful for the design of efficient coding and decoding methods.

Almost a quarter of a century later, a further step in this direction was given by Stichtenoth in [15]. There, he reproved the result of Tsfasman, Vladut and Zink by showing that there are sequences of transitive codes and self-dual codes (among others) over finite fields 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} of square cardinality q>4𝑞4q>4 attaining the Tsfasman-Vladut-Zink bound. Since he used the Galois closure of a recursive tower of function fields over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}, there is an improvement with respect to the codes given in [18]. Namely, we have, on the one side, a sequence of linear codes with a richer structure and, on the other side, a sequence of function fields which is more manageable, in principle, than the sequence of modular towers used in [18].

In this paper, we give another step by considering a different family of linear codes and showing that there are sequences of codes in this family attaining the Tsfasman-Vladut-Zink bound over finite fields of square cardinality 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}} with q𝑞q a prime power. These codes are finite direct sums of transitive codes and we call them block-transitive (see Definition 4.1). The advantage we have with this family of codes, with respect to others in previous works, lies in that we use the Galois closure of optimal towers, tamely and wildly ramified, defined in [9] and [7] which have been studied in detail in [3] and [4]. Thus we know explicitly, for instance, the degree of every extension as well as the structure of the Galois groups associated to these extensions, which are subgroups of the group of automorphisms of these codes. This is a valuable feature because we now have at our disposal more tools for a better and deeper understanding of the structure of these codes. At this point it is worth to mention that this is not available, to the best of our knowledge, for the transitive codes given in [15] because the Galois closure of the function fields of an optimal tower with respect to a proper subfield of the original field of rational functions was considered, and this is not the case treated in [4]. Another point worth mentioning is that the use of block-transitive codes allow us to use simpler arguments in more general results.

An outline of the paper is as follows. Sections 2–3 are preparatory while the main results are in Sections 4–7. More precisely, in Section 2 we briefly recall the basic definitions on algebraic codes and towers of algebraic function fields and their corresponding asymptotic behaviours. Also, in Definition 2.1 we introduce the notion of a (λ,δ)𝜆𝛿(\lambda,\delta)-bound, with the famous Tsfasman-Vladut-Zink bound being a particular case. In the next section we review algebraic-geometry codes (AG-codes for short) and the standard way to get asymptotically good sequences of AG-codes from sequences of towers, attaining such a (λ,δ)𝜆𝛿(\lambda,\delta)-bound. We also present some concrete realizations of good AG-codes using either recursive towers (Example 3.5) or lower bounds for the Ihara function (Examples 3.6 and 3.7).

Section 4 begins with the definition of block-transitive codes, that we use throughout the paper, together with some examples. Then, in Theorem 4.4 we give sufficient conditions on the splitting and ramification locus of a tower of function fields to be suitable for the construction of good r𝑟r-block transitive codes over a given finite field. In the next 2 sections we apply this result to prove the existence of families of block-transitive codes that are asymptotically good. In fact, using Theorem 4.4 and two quadratic optimal towers given in [7] and [9] we prove, in Theorem 5.1, the existence of sequences of r𝑟r-block transitive codes with r=q2−q𝑟superscript𝑞2𝑞r=q^{2}-q (resp. r=2​(p−1)𝑟2𝑝1r=2(p-1), p𝑝p an odd prime) attaining the Tsfasman-Vladut-Zink bound over 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}} (resp. 𝔽p2subscript𝔽superscript𝑝2\mathbb{F}_{p^{2}}). Then, in Theorem 6.1 we use good tamely ramified Hilbert class field towers with non zero splitting rate, given in [1], to prove the existence of good r𝑟r-block transitive codes over certain finite fields, not necessarily of square cardinality, of both odd and even characteristic and for r=2​n𝑟2𝑛r=2n or r=3​n𝑟3𝑛r=3n, respectively. The price we must pay for considering a wider class of finite fields is reflected in that we get weaker lower bounds for their performance compared to the ones obtained in Theorem 5.1 and [15] for the case of transitive codes. Finally we make some remarks on the existence of sequences of algebraic geometry codes with good performance over prime fields.

2. Asymptotic behaviour of codes and towers

A linear code of length n𝑛n, dimension k𝑘k and minimum distance d𝑑d over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} is an 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}-linear subspace 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} of 𝔽qnsuperscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑛\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} with k=dim𝒞𝑘dimension𝒞k=\dim\mathcal{C} and d=min⁡{d​(c,c′):c,c′∈𝒞,c≠c′}𝑑:𝑑𝑐superscript𝑐′𝑐superscript𝑐′𝒞𝑐superscript𝑐′d=\min\{d(c,c^{\prime}):c,c^{\prime}\in\mathcal{C},c\neq c^{\prime}\}, where d𝑑d is the Hamming distance in 𝔽qnsuperscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑛\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}. The elements of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} are usually called codewords and it is customary to say that 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is an [n,k,d]𝑛𝑘𝑑[n,k,d]-code over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}.

It is convenient to normalize the dimension and minimum distance of a code 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} with respect to the length, so that the information rate R=R(𝒞):=k/nR=R(\mathcal{C})\colon\!\!\!=k/n and the relative minimum distance δ=δ(𝒞):=d/n\delta=\delta(\mathcal{C})\colon\!\!\!=d/n of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} are in the unit interval for any [n,k,d]𝑛𝑘𝑑[n,k,d]-code 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. The goodness of an [n,k,d]𝑛𝑘𝑑[n,k,d]-code over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} is usually measured according to how big the sum R+δ𝑅𝛿R+\delta is, where

0<R+δ=kn+dn≤1+1n.0𝑅𝛿𝑘𝑛𝑑𝑛11𝑛0<R+\delta=\tfrac{k}{n}+\tfrac{d}{n}\leq 1+\tfrac{1}{n}.

Since k𝑘k and d𝑑d can not be arbitrarily large for fixed n𝑛n it is natural to allow arbitrarily large lengths. One way to do this is by considering a sequence {𝒞i}i=0∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖0\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} of [ni,ki,di]subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖[n_{i},k_{i},d_{i}]-codes over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} such that ni→∞→subscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}\rightarrow\infty as i→∞→𝑖i\rightarrow\infty and see how big the sum ki/ni+di/nisubscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖k_{i}/n_{i}+d_{i}/n_{i} can be as ni→∞→subscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}\rightarrow\infty.

On (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bounds for codes

A sequence {𝒞i}i=0∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖0\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} of [ni,ki,di]subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖[n_{i},k_{i},d_{i}]-codes over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} is asymptotically good over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} if

where ni→∞→subscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}\rightarrow\infty as i→∞→𝑖i\rightarrow\infty. In view of this, we propose the following

In other words, an (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound says more than the good asymptotic behaviour of the sequence of codes {𝒞i}i=0∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖0\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty}. In fact, any (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound gives a linear function as a lower bound for the Manin’s function αq​(δ)subscript𝛼𝑞𝛿\alpha_{q}(\delta); namely, for 0≤δ≤10𝛿10\leq\delta\leq 1, we have

(2.1) αq​(δ)≥ℓ−δ.subscript𝛼𝑞𝛿ℓ𝛿\alpha_{q}(\delta)\geq\ell-\delta.

Consider now the so called Ihara’s function (see, for instance, [12] and [16])

(2.2) A(q):=lim supg→∞Nq​(g)g,A(q)\colon\!\!=\limsup_{g\rightarrow\infty}\frac{N_{q}(g)}{g}\,,

(2.3) c​log⁡q≤A​(q)≤q−1𝑐𝑞𝐴𝑞𝑞1c\log q\leq A(q)\leq\sqrt{q}-1

(2.4) A​(q2)=q−1.𝐴superscript𝑞2𝑞1A(q^{2})=q-1.

There are some improvements and refinements of lower bounds for A​(q)𝐴𝑞A(q), as can be seen in [12].

The famous Tsfasman-Vladut-Zink bound over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} (TVZ-bound for short) is an example of an (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound with δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 and

(2.5) ℓ=1−A​(q)−1ℓ1𝐴superscript𝑞1\ell=1-A(q)^{-1}

if A​(q)>1𝐴𝑞1A(q)>1. For squares q≥49𝑞49q\geq 49, the TVZ-bound over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} improves the Gilbert-Varshamov bound which was considered, for some time, the best lower bound for Manin’s function (see [16], [15] and [17]). The GV-bound can also be seen as an (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound with

Towers

A function field (of one variable) over K𝐾K is a finite algebraic extension F𝐹F of the rational function field K​(x)𝐾𝑥K(x), where x𝑥x is a transcendental element over K𝐾K. Following [16], a sequence ℱ={Fi}i=0∞ℱsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} of function fields over a K𝐾K is called a tower if for every i≥0𝑖0i\geq 0 we have

  1. (1)

    Fi⊊Fi+1subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖1F_{i}\subsetneq F_{i+1};

  2. (2)

    the extension Fi+1/Fisubscript𝐹𝑖1subscript𝐹𝑖F_{i+1}/F_{i} is finite and separable;

  3. (3)

    K𝐾K is perfect and algebraically closed in Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}; and

  4. (4)

    the genus g​(Fi)𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖g(F_{i}) of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} tends to infinity, for i→∞→𝑖i\rightarrow\infty.

A tower ℱ={Fi}i=0∞ℱsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} over K𝐾K is called recursive if there exist a sequence of transcendental elements {xi}i=0∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖0\{x_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} over K𝐾K and a polynomial H​(X,Y)∈K​[X,Y]𝐻𝑋𝑌𝐾𝑋𝑌H(X,Y)\in K[X,Y] such that F0=K​(x0)subscript𝐹0𝐾subscript𝑥0F_{0}=K(x_{0}) and

Fi+1=Fi​(xi+1)whereH​(xi,xi+1)=0for all ​i≥0.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐹𝑖1subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1whereformulae-sequence𝐻subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖10for all 𝑖0F_{i+1}=F_{i}(x_{i+1})\quad\text{where}\quad H(x_{i},x_{i+1})=0\quad\text{for all }i\geq 0.

Now we define the concept of asymptotic behaviour of a tower. Let ℱ={Fi}i=0∞ℱsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} be a tower of function fields over K𝐾K. The genus of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} over F0subscript𝐹0F_{0} is defined as

(2.6) γ​(ℱ):=limi→∞g​(Fi)[Fi:F0].assign𝛾ℱsubscript→𝑖𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖delimited-[]:subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐹0\gamma(\mathcal{F}):=\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\frac{g(F_{i})}{[F_{i}:F_{0}]}.

where g​(Fi)𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖g(F_{i}) stands for the genus of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}. Notice that 0<γ​(ℱ)≤∞0𝛾ℱ0<\gamma(\mathcal{F})\leq\infty. When K𝐾K is finite, we denote by N​(Fi)𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖N(F_{i}) the number of rational places (i.e., places of degree one) of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} and the splitting rate of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} over F0subscript𝐹0F_{0} is defined as

(2.7) ν​(ℱ):=limi→∞N​(Fi)[Fi:F0].assign𝜈ℱsubscript→𝑖𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖delimited-[]:subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐹0\nu(\mathcal{F}):=\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\frac{N(F_{i})}{[F_{i}:F_{0}]}.

Notice that 0≤ν​(ℱ)<∞0𝜈ℱ0\leq\nu(\mathcal{F})<\infty.

A tower ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is called asymptotically good over a finite field K𝐾K if

ν​(ℱ)>0 and γ​(ℱ)<∞.formulae-sequence𝜈ℱ0 and 𝛾ℱ\nu(\mathcal{F})>0\qquad\text{ and }\qquad\gamma(\mathcal{F})<\infty.

Otherwise is called asymptotically bad. Equivalently, ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is asymptotically good over K𝐾K if and only if the limit of the tower ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is positive, i.e.

(2.8) λ​(ℱ):=limi→∞N​(Fi)g​(Fi)=ν​(ℱ)γ​(ℱ)>0.assign𝜆ℱsubscript→𝑖𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖𝜈ℱ𝛾ℱ0\lambda(\mathcal{F}):=\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\frac{N(F_{i})}{g(F_{i})}=\frac{\nu(\mathcal{F})}{\gamma(\mathcal{F})}>0.

Notice that if ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is a tower of function fields over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} then λ​(ℱ)≤A​(q)𝜆ℱ𝐴𝑞\lambda(\mathcal{F})\leq A(q). The tower is said to be optimal if λ​(ℱ)=A​(q)𝜆ℱ𝐴𝑞\lambda(\mathcal{F})=A(q).

3. Good AG-codes from sequences of function fields

Many families of 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}-linear codes have been proved to attain the TVZ-bound using Goppa ideas for constructing linear codes from the set of rational points of algebraic curves over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}. They are called algebraic geometry codes (or simply AG-codes) and some standard references for them are the books [16], [17], [10], [11] and [14].

We now recall their construction using the terminology of function fields (instead of algebraic curves). Let F𝐹F be an algebraic function field over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}, let G𝐺G and D=P1+⋯+Pn𝐷subscript𝑃1⋯subscript𝑃𝑛D=P_{1}+\cdots+P_{n} be disjoint divisors of F𝐹F, where P1,…,Pnsubscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑛P_{1},\ldots,P_{n} are different rational places of F𝐹F. Consider now the Riemann-Roch space ℒ​(G)={u∈F∖{0}:(u)≥−G}∪{0}ℒ𝐺conditional-set𝑢𝐹0𝑢𝐺0\mathcal{L}(G)=\{u\in F\smallsetminus\{0\}:(u)\geq-G\}\cup\{0\} associated to G𝐺G, where (u)𝑢(u) denotes the principal divisor of u∈F𝑢𝐹u\in F. The algebraic-geometry code defined by F𝐹F, D𝐷D and G𝐺G is

(3.1) 𝒞=Cℒ​(D,G)={(u​(P1),u​(P2),…,u​(Pn))∈𝔽qn:u∈ℒ​(G)},𝒞subscript𝐶ℒ𝐷𝐺conditional-set𝑢subscript𝑃1𝑢subscript𝑃2…𝑢subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑛𝑢ℒ𝐺\mathcal{C}=C_{\mathcal{L}}(D,G)=\big{\{}\big{(}u(P_{1}),u(P_{2}),\ldots,u(P_{n})\big{)}\in\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}:u\in\mathcal{L}(G)\big{\}},

with u​(Pi)𝑢subscript𝑃𝑖u(P_{i}) standing for the residue class of x𝑥x modulo Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}.

An important feature of these [n,k,d]𝑛𝑘𝑑[n,k,d]-codes is that lower bounds for k𝑘k and d𝑑d are available in terms of the genus g=g​(F)𝑔𝑔𝐹g=g(F) of F𝐹F and the degree deg⁡Gdegree𝐺\deg G of G𝐺G. More precisely, k≥deg⁡G+1−g𝑘degree𝐺1𝑔k\geq\deg G+1-g if deg⁡G<ndegree𝐺𝑛\deg G<n and d≥n−deg⁡G𝑑𝑛degree𝐺d\geq n-\deg G. Furthermore, if 2​g−2<deg⁡G<n2𝑔2degree𝐺𝑛2g-2<\deg G<n then k=deg⁡G+1−g𝑘degree𝐺1𝑔k=\deg G+1-g.

Good AG-codes from sequences

There is a standard way to construct a sequence of AG-codes over a finite field 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} attaining an (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound, as we show next. We include the proof for the convenience of the reader.

Proposition 3.1.

Let ℱ={Fi}i=0∞ℱsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} be a sequence of algebraic function fields over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} with 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} as their full field of constants and such that for each i≥0𝑖0i\geq 0 there are nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} rational places Pi,1,…,Pi,nisubscript𝑃𝑖1…subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖P_{i,1},\ldots,P_{i,n_{i}} in Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} with ni∈ℕsubscript𝑛𝑖ℕn_{i}\in\mathbb{N}. Let λ∈(0,1)𝜆01\lambda\in(0,1) and suppose that the following three conditions hold:

(a) ni→∞→subscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}\rightarrow\infty as i→∞→𝑖i\rightarrow\infty;

(b) there exists an index i0subscript𝑖0i_{0} such that g​(Fi)ni≤λ𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝜆\frac{g(F_{i})}{n_{i}}\leq\lambda for all i≥i0𝑖subscript𝑖0i\geq i_{0}; and

(c) for each i>0𝑖0i>0 there is a divisor Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} which is disjoint with Di:=Pi,1+⋯+Pi,niassignsubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖1⋯subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖D_{i}:=P_{i,1}+\cdots+P_{i,n_{i}} such that deg⁡Gi≤ni⋅α​(i)degreesubscript𝐺𝑖⋅subscript𝑛𝑖𝛼𝑖\deg G_{i}\leq n_{i}\cdot\alpha(i), where α:ℕ→ℝ:𝛼→ℕℝ\alpha:\mathbb{N}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} with α​(i)→0→𝛼𝑖0\alpha(i)\rightarrow 0 as i→∞→𝑖i\rightarrow\infty.

Then, there exists a sequence {ri}i=N∞⊂ℕsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑖𝑁ℕ\{r_{i}\}_{i=N}^{\infty}\subset\mathbb{N}, for certain N,𝑁N, such that ℱℱ\mathcal{F} induces a sequence 𝒢={𝒞i}i=N∞𝒢superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖𝑁\mathcal{G}=\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\}_{i=N}^{\infty} of asymptotically good AG-codes 𝒞i=Cℒ​(Di,ri​Gi)subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝐶ℒsubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i}=C_{\mathcal{L}}(D_{i},r_{i}G_{i}) attaining an (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound with ℓ=1−λℓ1𝜆\ell=1-\lambda. In particular, if λ=A​(q)−1𝜆𝐴superscript𝑞1\lambda=A(q)^{-1} the sequence 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} attains the TVZ-bound.

Proof.

Let δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1) be a fixed real number such that 1−δ>λ1𝛿𝜆1-\delta>\lambda. Note that δ𝛿\delta depends only on λ𝜆\lambda. Since α​(i)→0→𝛼𝑖0\alpha(i)\rightarrow 0 as i→∞→𝑖i\rightarrow\infty there exists an index i1subscript𝑖1i_{1} such that α​(i)<1−δ𝛼𝑖1𝛿\alpha(i)<1-\delta for i>i1𝑖subscript𝑖1i>i_{1}. Clearly, we can find a positive integer risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} such that, for every i≥i1𝑖subscript𝑖1i\geq i_{1}, we have

(3.2) 1−δ≥ri​deg⁡Gini>1−δ−α​(i).1𝛿subscript𝑟𝑖degreesubscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖1𝛿𝛼𝑖1-\delta\geq r_{i}\frac{\deg G_{i}}{n_{i}}>1-\delta-\alpha(i).

Let us consider now the AG-code 𝒞i=Cℒ​(Di,ri​Gi)subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝐶ℒsubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i}=C_{\mathcal{L}}(D_{i},r_{i}G_{i}) for i≥i0𝑖subscript𝑖0i\geq i_{0}. This is a code of length nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} and we have that its minimum distance disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} satisfies di≥ni−ri​deg⁡Gisubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖degreesubscript𝐺𝑖d_{i}\geq n_{i}-r_{i}\deg G_{i}. From this and the first inequality in (3.2) we see that the relative minimum distance 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i} satisfies

dini≥1−ri​deg⁡Gini≥δ.subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖1subscript𝑟𝑖degreesubscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝛿\frac{d_{i}}{n_{i}}\geq 1-r_{i}\frac{\deg G_{i}}{n_{i}}\geq\delta.

On the other hand, for the dimension kisubscript𝑘𝑖k_{i} of 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i} we have

ki≥ri​deg⁡Gi+1−g​(Fi)>ri​deg⁡Gi−g​(Fi).subscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖degreesubscript𝐺𝑖1𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖degreesubscript𝐺𝑖𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖k_{i}\geq r_{i}\deg G_{i}+1-g(F_{i})>r_{i}\deg G_{i}-g(F_{i}).

So that by (b) and the second inequality in (3.2) the information rate of 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i} satisfies

kini>ri​deg⁡Gini−g​(Fi)ni≥ri​deg⁡Gini−λ≥1−δ−α​(i)−λsubscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖degreesubscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖degreesubscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝜆1𝛿𝛼𝑖𝜆\frac{k_{i}}{n_{i}}>\frac{r_{i}\deg G_{i}}{n_{i}}-\frac{g(F_{i})}{n_{i}}\geq\frac{r_{i}\deg G_{i}}{n_{i}}-\lambda\geq 1-\delta-\alpha(i)-\lambda

for i≥N=max⁡{i0,i1}𝑖𝑁subscript𝑖0subscript𝑖1i\geq N=\max\{i_{0},i_{1}\}. Therefore,

lim infi→∞kini≥1−λ−δandlim infi→∞dini≥δ,formulae-sequencesubscriptlimit-infimum→𝑖subscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖1𝜆𝛿andsubscriptlimit-infimum→𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝛿\liminf_{i\rightarrow\infty}\frac{k_{i}}{n_{i}}\geq 1-\lambda-\delta\qquad\text{and}\qquad\liminf_{i\rightarrow\infty}\frac{d_{i}}{n_{i}}\geq\delta,

showing that the sequence of AG-codes {𝒞i}i=N∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖𝑁\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\}_{i=N}^{\infty} attains an (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound with ℓ=1−λℓ1𝜆\ell=1-\lambda. The remaining assertions follows directly from (2.5). ∎

Remark 3.2.

It is easy to see that in a concrete situation the crucial properties to have are conditions (a) and (b). In fact, once (a) and (b) are satisfied, condition (c) is not a problem unless we want the codes 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i} to have some additional structure besides linearity. More precisely, if we have (a) and (b) and we are just looking for a good sequence of linear codes, it suffices to consider Gi=Pisubscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖G_{i}=P_{i}, where Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} is a rational place of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} which is not in the support of Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}. However, this choice of Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} may not be adequate when, for instance, the invariance of Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} under some F0subscript𝐹0F_{0}-embedding of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} is needed as it happens in the cases of cyclic, transitive or block-transitive AG-codes (see Section 4 for details).

Remark 3.3.

By the definition of the Ihara function we have A​(q)≥nig​(Fi)≥λ−1𝐴𝑞subscript𝑛𝑖𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜆1A(q)\geq\frac{n_{i}}{g(F_{i})}\geq\lambda^{-1}, where λ𝜆\lambda is the constant in (b) of Proposition 3.1. By the second inequality in (2.3), we see that

λ≥1q−1.𝜆1𝑞1\lambda\geq\frac{1}{\sqrt{q}-1}.

This bound tell us that the construction of asymptotically good AG-codes over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} provided by Proposition 3.1 can not be carried out for q≤4𝑞4q\leq 4, since λ∈(0,1)𝜆01\lambda\in(0,1).

Remark 3.4.

Proposition 3.1 holds in the case of an asymptotically good tower ℱ={Fi}i=0∞ℱsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} of function fields over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} with limit λ​(ℱ)>1𝜆ℱ1\lambda(\mathcal{F})>1. In fact, if Nisubscript𝑁𝑖N_{i} is the number of rational places of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} then we can take ni=Ni−1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑁𝑖1n_{i}=N_{i}-1, Gi=Qisubscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑄𝑖G_{i}=Q_{i} (where Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} is the rational place of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} not considered among the nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} chosen rational places) and α​(i)=1/ni𝛼𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑖\alpha(i)=1/n_{i}. Then

limi→∞nig​(Fi)=limi→∞Ni−1g​(Fi)=λ​(ℱ)>1,subscript→𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖subscript→𝑖subscript𝑁𝑖1𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖𝜆ℱ1\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\frac{n_{i}}{g(F_{i})}=\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\frac{N_{i}-1}{g(F_{i})}=\lambda(\mathcal{F})>1,

so that there is an index i0subscript𝑖0i_{0} such that (b) of Proposition 3.1 holds for all i≥i0𝑖subscript𝑖0i\geq i_{0} with λ=λ​(ℱ)−1𝜆𝜆superscriptℱ1\lambda=\lambda(\mathcal{F})^{-1}. Clearly, items (a) and (c) also holds. Further, notice that if (b) holds using the sequence of function fields of a tower ℱ={Fi}i=0∞ℱsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}, then

limi→∞Nig​(Fi)≥lim infi→∞nig​(Fi)≥λ−1>1subscript→𝑖subscript𝑁𝑖𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptlimit-infimum→𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜆11\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\frac{N_{i}}{g(F_{i})}\geq\liminf_{i\rightarrow\infty}\frac{n_{i}}{g(F_{i})}\geq\lambda^{-1}>1

so that the limit of the considered tower is bigger than 111.

Some examples

We now use Proposition 3.1 to give examples of asymptotically good AG-codes over 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}}, 𝔽q3subscript𝔽superscript𝑞3\mathbb{F}_{q^{3}} and also over finite fields 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} of big enough cardinality. Of course, if we require something more than the linearity of the sequence of codes given by Proposition 3.1, the situation becomes much more delicate and restrictive (see the next Section).

Example 3.5.

For each q>2𝑞2q>2 there is a family of AG-codes over 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}} which is asymptotically good. To show this we just use the function fields in the recursive tower ℱ={Fi}i=0∞ℱsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} over 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}} of Garcia and Stichtenoth ([8]) whose defining equation is

(3.3) yq+y=xqxq−1+1.superscript𝑦𝑞𝑦superscript𝑥𝑞superscript𝑥𝑞11y^{q}+y=\frac{x^{q}}{x^{q-1}+1}.

It is known (see, for instance, [12, Example 5.4.1]) that N​(Fi)≥qi−1​(q2−q)+1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝑞𝑖1superscript𝑞2𝑞1N(F_{i})\geq q^{i-1}(q^{2}-q)+1 and

g​(Fi)={(qi2−1)2for i even,(qi+12−1)​(qi−12−1)for i odd.𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖casessuperscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑖212for i even,superscript𝑞𝑖121superscript𝑞𝑖121for i odd.g(F_{i})=\begin{cases}(q^{\frac{i}{2}}-1)^{2}&\quad\text{for $i$ even,}\vskip 3.0pt plus 1.0pt minus 1.0pt\\ (q^{\frac{i+1}{2}}-1)(q^{\frac{i-1}{2}}-1)&\quad\text{for $i$ odd.}\end{cases}

Thus, by taking ni=qi−1​(q2−q)subscript𝑛𝑖superscript𝑞𝑖1superscript𝑞2𝑞n_{i}=q^{i-1}(q^{2}-q), we have ni+1subscript𝑛𝑖1n_{i}+1 rational places Pi,1,…,Pi,ni,Qisubscript𝑃𝑖1…subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑄𝑖P_{i,1},\ldots,P_{i,n_{i}},Q_{i} in Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} and

nig​(Fi)≥q−1,subscript𝑛𝑖𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖𝑞1\frac{n_{i}}{g(F_{i})}\geq q-1,

for all i≥1𝑖1i\geq 1. We readily see that condition (a) in Proposition 3.1 holds and the same happens with condition (b) with λ=(q−1)−1=A​(q2)−1𝜆superscript𝑞11𝐴superscriptsuperscript𝑞21\lambda=(q-1)^{-1}=A(q^{2})^{-1}. Finally, by taking Gi=Qisubscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑄𝑖G_{i}=Q_{i}, we see that condition (c) also holds with α​(i)=1/ni𝛼𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑖\alpha(i)=1/n_{i}. In this way, by Proposition 3.1, the sequence {𝒞i}i∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖ℕ\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}} of AG-codes 𝒞i=C​(Di,Qi)subscript𝒞𝑖𝐶subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑄𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i}=C(D_{i},Q_{i}), with Di=Pi,1+⋯+Pi,nisubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖1⋯subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖D_{i}=P_{i,1}+\cdots+P_{i,n_{i}}, is asymptotically good and attains the TVZ-bound over 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}} for q≥3𝑞3q\geq 3.

Serre’s type lower bound for A​(q)𝐴𝑞A(q) give us a way to prove that the family of AG-codes over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} is asymptotically good for any q𝑞q large enough.

Example 3.6.

It is well known that A​(q)≥196​log2⁡q𝐴𝑞196subscript2𝑞A(q)\geq\tfrac{1}{96}\log_{2}q, for any prime power q𝑞q ([12, Theorem 5.2.9]). By definition of A​(q)𝐴𝑞A(q) there exists a sequence of function fields {Fi}i=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖1\{F_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty} over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} such that

Nig​(Fi)≥196​log2⁡q>1,subscript𝑁𝑖𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖196subscript2𝑞1\frac{N_{i}}{g(F_{i})}\geq\tfrac{1}{96}\log_{2}q>1,

for q>296𝑞superscript296q>2^{96}, where Ni=N​(Fi)subscript𝑁𝑖𝑁subscript𝐹𝑖N_{i}=N(F_{i}). Take ni=Ni−1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑁𝑖1n_{i}=N_{i}-1 and consider 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} with q>296𝑞superscript296q>2^{96}. Thus, condition (b) in Proposition 3.1 holds with λ=96log2⁡q𝜆96subscript2𝑞\lambda=\tfrac{96}{\log_{2}q} and, since g​(Fi)→∞→𝑔subscript𝐹𝑖g(F_{i})\rightarrow\infty as i→∞→𝑖i\rightarrow\infty, we must have that Ni→∞→subscript𝑁𝑖N_{i}\rightarrow\infty as i→∞→𝑖i\rightarrow\infty so that condition (a) also holds. The divisor Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} is simply the remaining rational place of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} after using the Ni−1subscript𝑁𝑖1N_{i}-1 rational places to define Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}. Clearly, condition (c) holds with α​(i)=1/ni𝛼𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑖\alpha(i)=1/n_{i}. Thus, by Proposition 3.1, there is a sequence of asymptotically good AG-codes over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} attaining an (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound for any q>296𝑞superscript296q>2^{96} with ℓ=1−96log2⁡qℓ196subscript2𝑞\ell=1-\tfrac{96}{\log_{2}q}.

Example 3.7.

There is a generalization of Zink’s lower bound for A​(q3)𝐴superscript𝑞3A(q^{3}) proved in [6], namely for any q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2 we have

A​(q3)≥2​(q2−1)q+2>1.𝐴superscript𝑞32superscript𝑞21𝑞21A(q^{3})\geq\tfrac{2(q^{2}-1)}{q+2}>1\,.

A similar argument as in Example 3.6 shows that for any q𝑞q there is an asymptotically good AG-code over 𝔽q3subscript𝔽superscript𝑞3\mathbb{F}_{q^{3}} attaining an (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound with ℓ=1−q+22​(q2−1)ℓ1𝑞22superscript𝑞21\ell=1-\tfrac{q+2}{2(q^{2}-1)}.

In the previous examples we have obtained a sequence of AG-codes attaining the TVZ-bound without any additional structure other than linearity. Can one construct good AG-codes with a prescribed property such as for instance cyclicity, transitivity or self-duality? For self-dual and transitive codes this was done in [15]. The problem for cyclic codes is still open. We will show later that there are families of so called block-transitive codes, which we now introduce, attaining the TVZ-bound.

4. Good block-transitive codes

4.1. Block-transitive codes

There is a natural action of the group 𝕊nsubscript𝕊𝑛\mathbb{S}_{n} on 𝔽qnsuperscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑛\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} given by

π⋅v=π⋅(v1,…,vn)=(vπ​(1),…,vπ​(n))⋅𝜋𝑣⋅𝜋subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛subscript𝑣𝜋1…subscript𝑣𝜋𝑛\pi\cdot v=\pi\cdot(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n})=(v_{\pi(1)},\ldots,v_{\pi(n)})

where π∈𝕊n𝜋subscript𝕊𝑛\pi\in\mathbb{S}_{n} and v=(v1,…,vn)∈𝔽qn𝑣subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑛v=(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n})\in\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}. The set of all π∈𝕊n𝜋subscript𝕊𝑛\pi\in\mathbb{S}_{n} such that π⋅c∈𝒞⋅𝜋𝑐𝒞\pi\cdot c\in\mathcal{C} for all codewords c𝑐c of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} forms a subgroup Perm​(𝒞)Perm𝒞\mathrm{Perm}(\mathcal{C}) of 𝕊nsubscript𝕊𝑛\mathbb{S}_{n} which is called the permutation group of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} (sometimes denoted by PAut​(𝒞)PAut𝒞\mathrm{PAut}(\mathcal{C})), that is

Perm​(𝒞)={π∈𝕊n:π⋅𝒞⊂𝒞}.Perm𝒞conditional-set𝜋subscript𝕊𝑛⋅𝜋𝒞𝒞\mathrm{Perm}(\mathcal{C})=\{\pi\in\mathbb{S}_{n}:\pi\cdot\mathcal{C}\subset\mathcal{C}\}.

A code 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is called transitive if there is a subgroup ΓΓ\Gamma of Perm​(𝒞)Perm𝒞\mathrm{Perm}(\mathcal{C}) acting transitively on the coordinates of the codewords of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}, i.e. for every 1≤i<j≤n1𝑖𝑗𝑛1\leq i<j\leq n there exists π∈Γ𝜋Γ\pi\in\Gamma such that π​(i)=j𝜋𝑖𝑗\pi(i)=j. An important subfamily of transitive codes is the class of cyclic codes. These are the codes which are invariant under the action of the cyclic shift s∈𝕊n𝑠subscript𝕊𝑛s\in\mathbb{S}_{n} defined by s​(1)=n𝑠1𝑛s(1)=n and s​(i)=i−1𝑠𝑖𝑖1s(i)=i-1 for i=2,…,n𝑖2…𝑛i=2,\ldots,n, i.e. a code 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is cyclic if s⋅c=(cs​(1),cs​(2),…,cs​(n))=(cn,c1,…,cn−1)∈𝒞⋅𝑠𝑐subscript𝑐𝑠1subscript𝑐𝑠2…subscript𝑐𝑠𝑛subscript𝑐𝑛subscript𝑐1…subscript𝑐𝑛1𝒞s\cdot c=(c_{s(1)},c_{s(2)},\ldots,c_{s(n)})=(c_{n},c_{1},\ldots,c_{n-1})\in\mathcal{C} for every c=(c1,c2,…,cn)∈𝒞𝑐subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2…subscript𝑐𝑛𝒞c=(c_{1},c_{2},\ldots,c_{n})\in\mathcal{C}.

Suppose now that for a fixed n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N} we have a partition

(4.1) n=m1+m2+⋯+mr𝑛subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2⋯subscript𝑚𝑟n=m_{1}+m_{2}+\cdots+m_{r}

where m1,…,mrsubscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑟m_{1},\ldots,m_{r} are positive integers. The set of all (π1,…,πr)∈𝕊m1×⋯×𝕊mrsubscript𝜋1…subscript𝜋𝑟subscript𝕊subscript𝑚1⋯subscript𝕊subscript𝑚𝑟(\pi_{1},\ldots,\pi_{r})\in\mathbb{S}_{m_{1}}\times\cdots\times\mathbb{S}_{m_{r}} such that (π1,…,πr)⋅c∈𝒞⋅subscript𝜋1…subscript𝜋𝑟𝑐𝒞(\pi_{1},\ldots,\pi_{r})\cdot c\in\mathcal{C} for all codewords c𝑐c of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} forms a subgroup of 𝕊m1×⋯×𝕊mrsubscript𝕊subscript𝑚1⋯subscript𝕊subscript𝑚𝑟\mathbb{S}_{m_{1}}\times\cdots\times\mathbb{S}_{m_{r}}. Definition 4.1.

Let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} be a code over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} of length n𝑛n. We say that 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is a block-transitive code if n𝑛n can be partitioned as in (4.1) for some r∈ℕ𝑟ℕr\in\mathbb{N} in such way that there is a subgroup ΓΓ\Gamma of Permr​(𝒞)subscriptPerm𝑟𝒞\mathrm{Perm}_{r}(\mathcal{C}) acting on 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} as above. If, in addition, m1=⋯=mr=msubscript𝑚1⋯subscript𝑚𝑟𝑚m_{1}=\cdots=m_{r}=m we say that 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is an r𝑟r-block-transitive code. Moreover if π1=⋯=πrsubscript𝜋1⋯subscript𝜋𝑟\pi_{1}=\cdots=\pi_{r} then we have the r𝑟r-quasi transitive codes defined by Bassa in his Thesis [2]. Notice that when r=1𝑟1r=1 we are just in the case of transitive codes.

We will next show how to construct geometric block transitive codes. We first recall some standard facts about places in Galois extensions. Let F𝐹F be a function field over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} and let E/F𝐸𝐹E/F be a finite field extension. If Q𝑄Q is a place of E𝐸E we will use the standard symbol Q|Pconditional𝑄𝑃Q|P to denote that Q𝑄Q lies over the place P𝑃P of F𝐹F, i.e. P=Q∩F𝑃𝑄𝐹P=Q\cap F. Now, assume that E𝐸E is a separable extension and that F=𝔽q​(x)𝐹subscript𝔽𝑞𝑥F=\mathbb{F}_{q}(x) is a rational function field over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}. It is well known (see, for instance, [16]) that the group Aut⁡(E/F)Aut𝐸𝐹\operatorname{Aut}(E/F) of 𝔽q​(x)subscript𝔽𝑞𝑥\mathbb{F}_{q}(x)-automorphisms of E𝐸E acts on the set of all places of E𝐸E and this action is extended naturally to divisors. Even more, if E/F𝐸𝐹E/F is Galois and {P1,…,Pn}subscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑛\{P_{1},\ldots,P_{n}\} is the set of all places of E𝐸E lying above a place P𝑃P of F𝐹F, then for each 1≤i<j≤n1𝑖𝑗𝑛1\leq i<j\leq n there exists σ∈Gal⁡(E/F)𝜎Gal𝐸𝐹\sigma\in\operatorname{Gal}(E/F) such that σ​(Pi)=Pj𝜎subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑃𝑗\sigma(P_{i})=P_{j}. This means that Gal⁡(E/F)Gal𝐸𝐹\operatorname{Gal}(E/F) acts transitively on the set {P1,…,Pn}subscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑛\{P_{1},\ldots,P_{n}\}.

Let Cℒ​(D,G)subscript𝐶ℒ𝐷𝐺C_{\mathcal{L}}(D,G) be an AG-code as in (3.1). Suppose now that σ​(G)=G𝜎𝐺𝐺\sigma(G)=G for any σ∈H𝜎𝐻\sigma\in H where H𝐻H is a subgroup of Aut⁡(E/F)Aut𝐸𝐹\operatorname{Aut}(E/F). Then, there is an action of H𝐻H on Cℒ​(D,G)subscript𝐶ℒ𝐷𝐺C_{\mathcal{L}}(D,G) defined as

σ⋅(u(P1),u(P2),…,u(Pn)):=(u(σ(P1)),u(σ(P2)),…,u(σ(Pn))).\sigma\cdot\big{(}u(P_{1}),u(P_{2}),\ldots,u(P_{n})\big{)}\colon\!\!=\big{(}u(\sigma(P_{1})),u(\sigma(P_{2})),\ldots,u(\sigma(P_{n}))\big{)}.

It is clear that all of this implies that the AG-code Cℒ​(D,G)subscript𝐶ℒ𝐷𝐺C_{\mathcal{L}}(D,G) is transitive if H𝐻H acts transitively on the set {P1,…,Pn}subscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑛\{P_{1},\ldots,P_{n}\}. Similarly, if H𝐻H is a cyclic group then, under the above conditions, the AG-code Cℒ​(D,G)subscript𝐶ℒ𝐷𝐺C_{\mathcal{L}}(D,G) is cyclic.

We first show how to construct a transitive AG-code. Let F𝐹F be an algebraic function field over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} and let P,Q𝑃𝑄P,Q be places in F𝐹F with P𝑃P rational. If P𝑃P splits completely in E𝐸E, then the AG-code 𝒞=CℒE​(D=P1+⋯+Pn,G)𝒞superscriptsubscript𝐶ℒ𝐸𝐷subscript𝑃1⋯subscript𝑃𝑛𝐺\mathcal{C}=C_{\mathcal{L}}^{E}(D=P_{1}+\cdots+P_{n},G), where Pi|Pconditionalsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑃P_{i}|P for 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n and G=∑Q′|QQ′𝐺subscriptconditionalsuperscript𝑄′𝑄superscript𝑄′G=\sum_{Q^{\prime}|Q}Q^{\prime} is the divisor obtained by summing over all the places in E𝐸E above Q𝑄Q, is well defined since each Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} is rational and disjoint from G𝐺G. Moreover, 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is transitive, since Γ=Gal⁡(E/F)ΓGal𝐸𝐹\Gamma=\operatorname{Gal}(E/F) acts transitively on D𝐷D and G𝐺G (hence, in particular, fixing them).

Now, to get r𝑟r-block transitive AG-codes we proceed as follows. Let E𝐸E be a finite Galois extension of degree m𝑚m of a function field F𝐹F over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}. 4.2. Good block-transitive codes

In this subsection we will present sufficient conditions to get good block-transitive AG-codes from towers.

We first review some basic definitions on ramification in towers of algebraic function fields, which will be used throughout the rest of the paper. The standard reference for all of this is [16]. Let F𝐹F be a function field over a perfect field K𝐾K and let E𝐸E be a field extension of F𝐹F of finite degree. Let Q𝑄Q and P𝑃P be places of E𝐸E and F𝐹F, respectively, with Q|Pconditional𝑄𝑃Q|P. Also, denote as usual by e​(Q|P)𝑒conditional𝑄𝑃e(Q|P) and f​(Q|P)𝑓conditional𝑄𝑃f(Q|P) the ramification index and the inertia degree of Q|Pconditional𝑄𝑃Q|P, respectively. We say that P𝑃P splits completely in E𝐸E if e​(Q|P)=f​(Q|P)=1𝑒conditional𝑄𝑃𝑓conditional𝑄𝑃1e(Q|P)=f(Q|P)=1 for any place Q𝑄Q of E𝐸E lying over P𝑃P (hence there are [E:F]delimited-[]:𝐸𝐹[E:F] places in E𝐸E above P𝑃P). We say that P𝑃P ramifies in E𝐸E if e​(Q|P)>1𝑒conditional𝑄𝑃1e(Q|P)>1 for some place Q𝑄Q of E𝐸E above P𝑃P and that it is totally ramified in E𝐸E if there is only one place Q𝑄Q of E𝐸E lying over P𝑃P and e(Q|P)=[E:F]e(Q|P)=[E:F] (hence f​(Q|P)=1𝑓conditional𝑄𝑃1f(Q|P)=1). It is known that the different exponent d​(Q|P)𝑑conditional𝑄𝑃d(Q|P) satisfies e​(Q|P)−1≤d​(Q|P)𝑒conditional𝑄𝑃1𝑑conditional𝑄𝑃e(Q|P)-1\leq d(Q|P). If b∈ℝ𝑏ℝb\in\mathbb{R}, the extension E/F𝐸𝐹E/F is called b-bounded (see [8]) if for any place P𝑃P of F𝐹F and any place Q𝑄Q of E𝐸E lying over P𝑃P we have

d​(Q|P)≤b​(e​(Q|P)−1).𝑑conditional𝑄𝑃𝑏𝑒conditional𝑄𝑃1d(Q|P)\leq b(e(Q|P)-1).

Let ℱ={Fi}i=0∞ℱsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} be a tower of function fields over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}. The ramification locus R​(ℱ)𝑅ℱR(\mathcal{F}) of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is the set of places P𝑃P of F0subscript𝐹0F_{0} such that P𝑃P is ramified in Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} for some i≥1𝑖1i\geq 1. The splitting locus S​p​(ℱ)𝑆𝑝ℱSp(\mathcal{F}) of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is the set of rational places P𝑃P of F0subscript𝐹0F_{0} such that P𝑃P splits completely in Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} for all i≥1𝑖1i\geq 1. Notice that the set R​(ℱ)𝑅ℱR(\mathcal{F}) could be empty, finite or even infinite whereas the set S​p​(ℱ)𝑆𝑝ℱSp(\mathcal{F}) could be empty or finite but never infinite. A place P𝑃P of F0subscript𝐹0F_{0} is totally ramified in the tower if for each i≥1𝑖1i\geq 1 there is only one place Q𝑄Q of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} lying over P𝑃P and e(Q|P)=[Fi:F0]e(Q|P)=[F_{i}:F_{0}]. We introduce the following definition.

Definition 4.2.

Given an integer μ>1𝜇1\mu>1 and a tower ℱ={Fi}i=0∞ℱsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty}, a place P𝑃P of F0subscript𝐹0F_{0} is absolutely μ𝜇\mu-ramified in ℱℱ\mathcal{F} if for each i≥1𝑖1i\geq 1 and any place Q𝑄Q of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} lying over P𝑃P we have that e​(R|Q)≥μ𝑒conditional𝑅𝑄𝜇e(R|Q)\geq\mu for any place R𝑅R of Fi+1subscript𝐹𝑖1F_{i+1} lying over Q𝑄Q.

The tower ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is called tame or tamely ramified if for any i≥0𝑖0i\geq 0, any place P𝑃P of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} and any place Q𝑄Q of Fi+1subscript𝐹𝑖1F_{i+1} lying over P𝑃P, the ramification index e​(Q|P)𝑒conditional𝑄𝑃e(Q|P) is not divisible by the characteristic of 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}. Otherwise, ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is called wild or wildly ramified. Furthermore, ℱℱ\mathcal{F} has Galois steps if each extension Fi+1/Fisubscript𝐹𝑖1subscript𝐹𝑖F_{i+1}/F_{i} is Galois. One says that ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is a b-bounded tower if each extension Fi+1/Fisubscript𝐹𝑖1subscript𝐹𝑖F_{i+1}/F_{i} is a b𝑏b-bounded Galois p𝑝p-extension where p=char​(𝔽q)𝑝charsubscript𝔽𝑞p=\textrm{char}(\mathbb{F}_{q}). If each extension Fi/F0subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐹0F_{i}/F_{0} is Galois, ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is said to be a Galois tower over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}.

Conditions for the existence of good block-transitive AG-codes from towers

It is known that the class of transitive codes attains the TVZ-bound over 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}} ([15]), i.e., by (2.4)–(2.5), an (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound with

(4.2) ℓ=1−1A​(q2)=1−1q−1.ℓ11𝐴superscript𝑞211𝑞1\ell=1-\frac{1}{A(q^{2})}=1-\frac{1}{q-1}.

Also, from [2], the class of r𝑟r-quasi transitive codes attains an (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound over 𝔽q3subscript𝔽superscript𝑞3\mathbb{F}_{q^{3}} with

ℓ=1−q+22​r​(q−1).ℓ1𝑞22𝑟𝑞1\ell=1-\frac{q+2}{2r(q-1)}.

In both cases wildly ramified towers were used. We will later prove a general result for the case of r𝑟r-block transitive codes by using both wildly and tamely ramified towers (see Section 6).

Remark 4.3.

Note that, by definition, block-transitive codes are direct sums of transitive codes. It is clear that the direct sum of asymptotically good codes is again good. However, even though the family of transitive codes is asymptotically good, nothing can be said in general about the asymptotic behaviour of block-transitive codes, which are a direct sum of possibly different transitive codes.

We now present a general result giving sufficient conditions to have good r𝑟r-block transitive AG-codes by using the Galois closure of a certain class of towers.

Theorem 4.4.

Let ℱ={Fi}i=0∞ℱsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} be either a tamely ramified tower with Galois steps or a 222-bounded tower over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} with non empty splitting locus S​p​(ℱ)𝑆𝑝ℱSp(\mathcal{F}) and non empty ramification locus R​(ℱ)𝑅ℱR(\mathcal{F}). Suppose there are finite sets ΓΓ\Gamma and ΩΩ\Omega of rational places of F0subscript𝐹0F_{0} such that R​(ℱ)⊂Γ𝑅ℱΓR(\mathcal{F})\subset\Gamma and Ω⊂S​p​(ℱ)Ω𝑆𝑝ℱ\Omega\subset Sp(\mathcal{F}) with

(4.3) 0<g0−1+ϵ​t<r,0subscript𝑔01italic-ϵ𝑡𝑟0<g_{0}-1+\epsilon t<r,

where g0=g​(F0)subscript𝑔0𝑔subscript𝐹0g_{0}=g(F_{0}), t=|Γ|𝑡Γt=|\Gamma|, r=|Ω|𝑟Ωr=|\Omega| and ϵ=12italic-ϵ12\epsilon=\tfrac{1}{2} if ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is tamely ramified or ϵ=1italic-ϵ1\epsilon=1 otherwise. If there is a place P0∈R​(ℱ)subscript𝑃0𝑅ℱP_{0}\in R(\mathcal{F}) which is absolutely μ𝜇\mu-ramified in ℱℱ\mathcal{F} for some μ>1𝜇1\mu>1, then there exists a sequence 𝒢={𝒞i}i=0∞𝒢superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{G}=\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} of r𝑟r-block transitive AG-codes over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} attaining a (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound with

(4.4) ℓ=1−g0−1+ϵ​tr.ℓ1subscript𝑔01italic-ϵ𝑡𝑟\ell=1-\frac{g_{0}-1+\epsilon t}{r}.

In particular, the Manin’s function satisfies αq​(δ)≥ℓ−δsubscript𝛼𝑞𝛿ℓ𝛿\alpha_{q}(\delta)\geq\ell-\delta. Moreover, the sequence 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is defined over the Galois closure ℰℰ\mathcal{E} of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} with limit λ​(ℰ)>1𝜆ℰ1\lambda(\mathcal{E})>1.

Proof.

We divide the proof in several steps for clarity.

Step 1: the Galois closure ℰℰ\mathcal{E} of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}. Let Fi′subscriptsuperscript𝐹′𝑖F^{\prime}_{i} be the Galois closure of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} over F0subscript𝐹0F_{0}, which is simply the compositum of fields of the form σ​(Fi)𝜎subscript𝐹𝑖\sigma(F_{i}) where σ𝜎\sigma ranges over the finitely many F0subscript𝐹0F_{0}-embeddings of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} into an algebraic closure F0¯¯subscript𝐹0\overline{F_{0}} of F0subscript𝐹0F_{0}. Denote by ℰ={Fi′}i=0∞ℰsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐹′𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{E}=\{F^{\prime}_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} the tower which is the Galois closure of ℱℱ\mathcal{F}.

Remark 4.5.

At first, it seems that the condition of having an absolutely μ𝜇\mu-ramified place in the tower ℱℱ\mathcal{F} in Theorem 4.4 is only for technical reasons, but the above lower bound shows that μ𝜇\mu has something to do also with the AG-codes constructed from ℱℱ\mathcal{F}.

5. Good block-transitive codes attaining the TVZ-bound

As a consequence of Theorem 4.4, we will next show that the TVZ-bound can be attained by sequences of certain block-transitive codes (constructed from towers of function fields) whose lengths can be computed explicitly while their minimum distances and dimensions can be estimated in terms of the cardinality of the considered finite field 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}. The structure of the Galois groups acting on the codes is also known.

From wildly ramified towers

We will construct good r𝑟r-block transitive codes over finite fields of square cardinality 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}}, with r=q2−q𝑟superscript𝑞2𝑞r=q^{2}-q. We will need the following notation; let q>2𝑞2q>2 and put

(5.1) mi={q2​i−1(resp. q2​i−1−⌊i/2⌋)if 1≤i≤2 and q is odd (resp. even),q3​i−3(resp. q3​i−3−⌊i/2⌋)if i≥3 and q is odd (resp. even),subscript𝑚𝑖casessuperscript𝑞2𝑖1(resp. q2i−1−⌊i/2⌋)if 1≤i≤2 and q is odd (resp. even),superscript𝑞3𝑖3(resp. q3i−3−⌊i/2⌋)if i≥3 and q is odd (resp. even),m_{i}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}q^{2i-1}\quad\text{(resp. $q^{2i-1-\lfloor i/2\rfloor})$}&\qquad\text{if $1\leq i\leq 2$ and $q$ is odd (resp.\@ even),}\vskip 6.0pt plus 2.0pt minus 2.0pt\\ q^{3i-3}\quad\text{(resp. $q^{3i-3-\lfloor i/2\rfloor})$}&\qquad\text{if $i\geq 3$ and $q$ is odd (resp.\@ even),}\end{array}\right.

for each i∈ℕ𝑖ℕi\in\mathbb{N}.

Theorem 5.1.

Let q>2𝑞2q>2 be a prime power. Then, there exists a sequence 𝒢={𝒞i}i=1∞𝒢superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖1\mathcal{G}=\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty} of r𝑟r-block transitive codes over 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}}, with r=q2−q𝑟superscript𝑞2𝑞r=q^{2}-q, attaining the TVZ-bound. Each 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i} is an [ni=r​mi,ki,di]delimited-[]subscript𝑛𝑖𝑟subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖[n_{i}=rm_{i},k_{i},d_{i}]-code, where misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} is as in (5.1). (5.2) di≥δ​(q2−q)​miandki≥{(1−δ)​(q2−q)−(q+q−i)}​miformulae-sequencesubscript𝑑𝑖𝛿superscript𝑞2𝑞subscript𝑚𝑖andsubscript𝑘𝑖1𝛿superscript𝑞2𝑞𝑞superscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖d_{i}\geq\delta\,(q^{2}-q)m_{i}\qquad\text{and}\qquad k_{i}\geq\{(1-\delta)(q^{2}-q)-(q+q^{-i})\}m_{i}

for each i≥1𝑖1i\geq 1, where the second inequality is non trivial for 0<δ<1−1r​(q+q−i)0𝛿11𝑟𝑞superscript𝑞𝑖0<\delta<1-\tfrac{1}{r}(q+q^{-i}).

Proof.

Let us consider now the wildly ramified tower ℱ={Fi}i=0∞ℱsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑖0\mathcal{F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i=0}^{\infty} over 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}} recursively defined by the equation

yq+y=xqxq−1+1,superscript𝑦𝑞𝑦superscript𝑥𝑞superscript𝑥𝑞11y^{q}+y=\frac{x^{q}}{x^{q-1}+1},

whose optimality was first proved in [7] (see also Section 7.4 of [16]). From these works we know that ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is a 222-bounded tower over 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}}, the pole P∞subscript𝑃P_{\infty} of x0subscript𝑥0x_{0} in F0=𝔽q2​(x0)subscript𝐹0subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2subscript𝑥0F_{0}=\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}}(x_{0}) is totally ramified in ℱℱ\mathcal{F}, so that P∞subscript𝑃P_{\infty} is absolutely q𝑞q-ramified in ℱℱ\mathcal{F}, at least q2−qsuperscript𝑞2𝑞q^{2}-q rational places of 𝔽q2subscript𝔽superscript𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q^{2}} split completely in ℱℱ\mathcal{F} and the ramification locus R​(ℱ)𝑅ℱR(\mathcal{F}) has at most q+1𝑞1q+1 elements, i.e. q2−q≤|S​p​(ℱ)|superscript𝑞2𝑞𝑆𝑝ℱq^{2}-q\leq|Sp(\mathcal{F})| and |R​(ℱ)|≤q+1𝑅ℱ𝑞1|R(\mathcal{F})|\leq q+1.

Thus, we are in the conditions of Theorem 4.4 with

μ=q,ϵ=1,g0=0,r=q2−qandt=q+1.formulae-sequence𝜇𝑞formulae-sequenceitalic-ϵ1formulae-sequencesubscript𝑔00formulae-sequence𝑟superscript𝑞2𝑞and𝑡𝑞1\mu=q,\qquad\epsilon=1,\qquad g_{0}=0,\qquad r=q^{2}-q\qquad\text{and}\qquad t=q+1.

6. Good block-transitive codes from class field towers

Now we prove the existence of good r𝑟r-block transitive codes over finite fields, not necessarily of quadratic cardinality. This result will also allow us to give examples of asymptotically good r𝑟r-block transitive codes for many values of r𝑟r different from the ones given in Theorems 5.1 and 5.3. The price we must pay is that of having weaker bounds for the performance of the codes.

We will need the following notations. Given n,m∈ℤ𝑛𝑚ℤn,m\in\mathbb{Z}, we define the auxiliary function

(6.1) εn​(m)={1if n∣m,0if n∤m.subscript𝜀𝑛𝑚cases1if n∣m,0if n∤m.\varepsilon_{n}(m)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}1&\quad\text{if $n\mid m$,}\vskip 3.0pt plus 1.0pt minus 1.0pt\\ 0&\quad\text{if $n\nmid m$.}\end{array}\right.

Also, for a polynomial h∈𝔽q​[t]ℎsubscript𝔽𝑞delimited-[]𝑡h\in\mathbb{F}_{q}[t], we define

(6.2) Sq2​(h)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑞2ℎ\displaystyle S_{q}^{2}(h) ={β∈𝔽q:h​(β) is a non zero square in 𝔽q},absentconditional-set𝛽subscript𝔽𝑞h(β) is a non zero square in 𝔽q\displaystyle=\{\beta\in\mathbb{F}_{q}:\text{$h(\beta)$ is a non zero square in $\mathbb{F}_{q}$}\},
Sq3​(h)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑞3ℎ\displaystyle S_{q}^{3}(h) ={β∈𝔽q:h​(β) is a non zero cube in 𝔽q}.absentconditional-set𝛽subscript𝔽𝑞h(β) is a non zero cube in 𝔽q\displaystyle=\{\beta\in\mathbb{F}_{q}:\text{$h(\beta)$ is a non zero cube in $\mathbb{F}_{q}$}\}.
Theorem 6.1.

Let h∈𝔽q​[t]ℎsubscript𝔽𝑞delimited-[]𝑡h\in\mathbb{F}_{q}[t] be a monic and separable polynomial of degree m𝑚m such that it splits completely into linear factors over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}.

(a) Let q𝑞q be odd. Suppose there is a set Σo⊂Sq2​(h)subscriptΣ𝑜superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑞2ℎ\Sigma_{o}\subset S_{q}^{2}(h) such that u=|Σo|>0𝑢subscriptΣ𝑜0u=|\Sigma_{o}|>0 and

Proof.

Let x𝑥x be a transcendental element over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} and let K=𝔽q​(x)𝐾subscript𝔽𝑞𝑥K=\mathbb{F}_{q}(x) the rational field over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}. We will use the extensions of K𝐾K given by the super-elliptic equation

(6.5) yn=h​(x)superscript𝑦𝑛ℎ𝑥y^{n}=h(x)

with n=2𝑛2n=2 or 333, depending on whether q𝑞q is odd or even, respectively.

We now divide the proof in three parts: (i) and (ii) consider the cases of q𝑞q odd and even respectively, while in (iii) we prove items (a) and (b) of the theorem.

(i) Let q𝑞q be odd. The case q=22​s+1𝑞superscript22𝑠1q=2^{2s+1}, not covered in Theorem 6.1, cannot be handled with the method used in the proof. We will now show, as a corollary of the previous theorem, that there are asymptotically good N𝑁N-block transitive codes over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}, with N𝑁N a multiple of 222 or 333, for q𝑞q big enough depending on N𝑁N.

Theorem 6.3.

Let u≥2𝑢2u\geq 2 and v≥5𝑣5v\geq 5. Then,

(a) there are sequences ℱusubscriptℱ𝑢\mathcal{F}_{u} of asymptotically good 2​u2𝑢2u-block transitive codes over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} for every q𝑞q odd with q≥4​(u+2)2𝑞4superscript𝑢22q\geq 4(u+2)^{2} and,

7. Good block transitive codes over prime fields

Here we focus in more detail on the construction of asymptotically good sequences of block transitive codes over prime fields 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}. Theorem 6.3 assures that good sequences of both 2​u2𝑢2u-block transitive codes over 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p} exist, but the minimum possible value of p𝑝p grows quadratically with u𝑢u. We want to find good sequences of r𝑟r-block transitive codes for small values of r𝑟r over the smallest prime fields possible. In particular, we want to produce good 444-block transitive codes (which are the more cyclic-like we can get) over small prime fields.

Restriction of good codes to prime fields

Let p𝑝p be a prime. We respectively denote by k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime} and d′superscript𝑑′d^{\prime} the dimension and minimum distance of the restriction code 𝒞′superscript𝒞′\mathcal{C}^{\prime} over 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p} of an [n,k,d]𝑛𝑘𝑑[n,k,d]-code 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} over 𝔽pssubscript𝔽superscript𝑝𝑠\mathbb{F}_{p^{s}}. We clearly have d′≥dsuperscript𝑑′𝑑d^{\prime}\geq d and, from [16, Lemma 9.1.3], also

(7.1) k′≥k−(s−1)​(n−k)=s​k−(s−1)​n.superscript𝑘′𝑘𝑠1𝑛𝑘𝑠𝑘𝑠1𝑛k^{\prime}\geq k-(s-1)(n-k)=sk-(s-1)n.

Consider a sequence of [ni,ki,di]subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖[n_{i},k_{i},d_{i}]-codes {𝒞i}subscript𝒞𝑖\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\} over 𝔽pssubscript𝔽superscript𝑝𝑠\mathbb{F}_{p^{s}} attaining an (ℓ,δ)ℓ𝛿(\ell,\delta)-bound. Then, we have that kini≥ℓ−δsubscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖ℓ𝛿\frac{k_{i}}{n_{i}}\geq\ell-\delta and dini≥δsubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝛿\frac{d_{i}}{n_{i}}\geq\delta, for i𝑖i big enough. Thus, by (7.1),

(7.2) Ri′=ki′ni≥s​kini−s+1≥s​ℓ−s+1−s​δandδi′=di′ni≥dini≥δ.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖′subscript𝑛𝑖𝑠subscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑠1𝑠ℓ𝑠1𝑠𝛿andsuperscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖′subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝛿R_{i}^{\prime}=\frac{k_{i}^{\prime}}{n_{i}}\geq\frac{sk_{i}}{n_{i}}-s+1\geq s\ell-s+1-s\delta\qquad\text{and}\qquad\delta_{i}^{\prime}=\frac{d_{i}^{\prime}}{n_{i}}\geq\frac{d_{i}}{n_{i}}\geq\delta.

If {𝒞i}i=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖1\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty} also attains the TVZ-bound over 𝔽p2​msubscript𝔽superscript𝑝2𝑚\mathbb{F}_{p^{2m}}, we have

αp2​m​(δ)≥1−1pm−1−δsubscript𝛼superscript𝑝2𝑚𝛿11superscript𝑝𝑚1𝛿\alpha_{p^{2m}}(\delta)\geq 1-\frac{1}{p^{m}-1}-\delta

where ℓ=1−1pm−1ℓ11superscript𝑝𝑚1\ell=1-\frac{1}{p^{m}-1}. Then, by (2.1), (2.4) and (7.2), the following lower bound for Manin’s function over the prime field 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p} holds

(7.3) αp​(δ)≥1−2​mpm−1−2​m​δ.subscript𝛼𝑝𝛿12𝑚superscript𝑝𝑚12𝑚𝛿\alpha_{p}(\delta)\geq 1-\frac{2m}{p^{m}-1}-2m\delta.

That is, we cannot assure that the restricted sequence {𝒞i′}superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖′\{\mathcal{C}_{i}^{\prime}\} of codes satisfy an (ℓ′,δ′)superscriptℓ′superscript𝛿′(\ell^{\prime},\delta^{\prime})-bound, but they still have a good performance. Furthermore, we have the following.

Lemma 7.1.

Let p𝑝p be a prime and 𝒢={𝒞i}i=1∞𝒢superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖1\mathcal{G}=\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty} a sequence of codes over 𝔽p2​msubscript𝔽superscript𝑝2𝑚\mathbb{F}_{p^{2m}} attaining the TVZ-bound. Then, if p≥5𝑝5p\geq 5, the sequence of restricted codes 𝒢′={𝒞i′}i=1∞superscript𝒢′superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖′𝑖1\mathcal{G}^{\prime}=\{\mathcal{C}_{i}^{\prime}\}_{i=1}^{\infty} is asymptotically good over 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}. Also, 𝒢′superscript𝒢′\mathcal{G}^{\prime} is asymptotically good over 𝔽2subscript𝔽2\mathbb{F}_{2} if m≥3𝑚3m\geq 3 and over 𝔽3subscript𝔽3\mathbb{F}_{3} if m≥2𝑚2m\geq 2.

Proof.

By (7.2) we only need to show that 0<2​m​(ℓ−δ−1)+1<102𝑚ℓ𝛿1110<2m(\ell-\delta-1)+1<1. Since 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} attains the TVZ-bound over 𝔽p2​msubscript𝔽superscript𝑝2𝑚\mathbb{F}_{p^{2m}}, we have ℓ=1−1pm−1ℓ11superscript𝑝𝑚1\ell=1-\tfrac{1}{p^{m}-1}. This is equivalent to

0<12​m−1pm−1.012𝑚1superscript𝑝𝑚10<\tfrac{1}{2m}-\tfrac{1}{p^{m}-1}.

This holds for p=2𝑝2p=2 and m≥3𝑚3m\geq 3, p=3𝑝3p=3 and m≥2𝑚2m\geq 2 and for p≥5𝑝5p\geq 5 for every m𝑚m. ∎

Now, we show that there are sequences of asymptotically good r𝑟r-block transitive codes over 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}, for every prime p𝑝p and some r𝑟r depending on p𝑝p.

Proposition 7.2.

Let p𝑝p be a prime number and m𝑚m an integer.

  1. (a)

    There are asymptotically good 2​(p−1)2𝑝12(p-1)-block transitive codes over 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}, for any p≥13𝑝13p\geq 13.

  2. (b)

    There are asymptotically good pm​(pm−1)superscript𝑝𝑚superscript𝑝𝑚1p^{m}(p^{m}-1)-block transitive codes over 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}, for every m≥3𝑚3m\geq 3 if p=2𝑝2p=2, m≥2𝑚2m\geq 2 if p=3𝑝3p=3 and m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1 if p≥5𝑝5p\geq 5.

Proof.

The result follows directly from Theorems 5.1 and 5.3 and Lemma 7.1. ∎

Remark 7.3.

Notice that by the results in [15] and using Lemma 7.1 we can assure the existence of asymptotically good sequences of transitive codes and self-dual codes over prime fields.

Good 444-block transitive codes

Now we present a direct construction of good block-transitive AG-codes over certain prime fields by using Theorem 6.1 and properties of the Legendre symbol. We focus on the case of 444-block transitive codes. We have seen in the previous section (Example 6.4) that good 444-block transitive codes exist for every prime field 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p} with p≥67𝑝67p\geq 67. Here we will prove that they also exist for every prime p≥13𝑝13p\geq 13 by using properties of Legendre symbols.

Let m=2​n+1𝑚2𝑛1m=2n+1 and let us consider the set

Rn={α1,…,αn}⊂𝔽q,subscript𝑅𝑛subscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝑛subscript𝔽𝑞R_{n}=\{\alpha_{1},\ldots,\alpha_{n}\}\subset\mathbb{F}_{q},

such that αi−1∉Rnsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖1subscript𝑅𝑛\alpha_{i}^{-1}\notin R_{n} for i=1,…,n𝑖1…𝑛i=1,\ldots,n, where q𝑞q is odd. We define the separable polynomial of degree m𝑚m

(7.4) h​(t)=(t+1)​∏i=1n(t−αi)​(t−αi−1).ℎ𝑡𝑡1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛𝑡subscript𝛼𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖1h(t)=(t+1)\prod_{i=1}^{n}(t-\alpha_{i})(t-\alpha_{i}^{-1}).

Since we are interested in 444-block transitive codes we need, according to Theorem 61, a separable polynomial over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} of degree m𝑚m that splits into linear factors over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} and a set Σo⊂Sq2subscriptΣ𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑆2𝑞\Sigma_{o}\subset S^{2}_{q} with two elements. Notice that if we take a polynomial h​(t)ℎ𝑡h(t) as in (7.4) then h​(t)ℎ𝑡h(t) satisfies the requirements and since h​(0)=1ℎ01h(0)=1 we also have that 0∈Σo0subscriptΣ𝑜0\in\Sigma_{o}. Thus if we choose a polynomial as in (7.4) we just need one more element in ΣosubscriptΣ𝑜\Sigma_{o}. On the other hand, from condition (30) of Theorem 61 for u=2𝑢2u=2 we see that we have to take m=9𝑚9m=9.

Proposition 7.4.

There are asymptotically good 444-block transitive codes over 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}, for every prime p≥13𝑝13p\geq 13.

Proof.

By the above comments we consider a polynomial h​(t)ℎ𝑡h(t) as in (7.4) of degree 999 so that n=4𝑛4n=4. It remains to find an element 0≠β∈𝔽p0𝛽subscript𝔽𝑝0\neq\beta\in\mathbb{F}_{p} such that h​(β)ℎ𝛽h(\beta) is a nonzero square in 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}.

It is easy to check that for p≤11𝑝11p\leq 11 there is no separable polynomial of degree 999 satisfying the required conditions. Let p=13𝑝13p=13, 171717, 191919 and 232323. It is straightforward to check that the elements α1=2subscript𝛼12\alpha_{1}=2, α2=3subscript𝛼23\alpha_{2}=3, α3=4subscript𝛼34\alpha_{3}=4 and α4=5subscript𝛼45\alpha_{4}=5 of 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p} with p=13,17𝑝1317p=13,17 or 232323 satisfy αi−1∉R4={2,3,4,5}superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖1subscript𝑅42345\alpha_{i}^{-1}\notin R_{4}=\{2,3,4,5\} for i=1,…,4𝑖1…4i=1,\ldots,4. and

For small values of r𝑟r, we will give asymptotically good sequences of r𝑟r-bt codes over 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}, generated by explicit sets Rnsubscript𝑅𝑛R_{n} and Susubscript𝑆𝑢S_{u}.

It suffices to check that (h​(a)p)=1ℎ𝑎𝑝1\big{(}\frac{h(a)}{p}\big{)}=1, where (⋅p)⋅𝑝(\frac{\cdot}{p}) denotes the Legendre symbol modulo p𝑝p (Jacobi symbol for p𝑝p odd not prime). since s𝑠s is odd and (⋅p)2=1superscript⋅𝑝21(\tfrac{\cdot}{p})^{2}=1.

Note that this last expression involves only k𝑘k and not its inverse. For instance, for p≥37𝑝37p\geq 37 we can take the j=2,…,7𝑗2…7j=2,\ldots,7 and

for every s≥1𝑠1s\geq 1 odd. This reduces the search of a non zero element α∈𝔽p𝛼subscript𝔽𝑝\alpha\in\mathbb{F}_{p} such that h​(α)ℎ𝛼h(\alpha) is a non zero square in 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p} to the computation of Legendre symbols for a given prime p≥37𝑝37p\geq 37.

Corollary 7.5.

There are asymptotically good 4-block transitive AG-codes over 𝔽pssubscript𝔽superscript𝑝𝑠\mathbb{F}_{p^{s}}, for any s≥1𝑠1s\geq 1 odd, generated by the sets R4={2,3,4,5}subscript𝑅42345R_{4}=\{2,3,4,5\} and Σo={0,p−j}subscriptΣ𝑜0𝑝𝑗\Sigma_{o}=\{0,p-j\} in 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}, with 2≤j≤72𝑗72\leq j\leq 7, for infinitely many prime numbers p𝑝p. For instance, for every prime of the form p=220​k+ℓ𝑝220𝑘ℓp=220k+\ell, with k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N} and ℓ∈{1,9,11,19}ℓ191119\ell\in\{1,9,11,19\}, the element p−2𝑝2p-2 together with the set S𝑆S generates an asymptotically good sequence of 444-block transitive codes over 𝔽pssubscript𝔽superscript𝑝𝑠\mathbb{F}_{p^{s}} for every s𝑠s odd.

Proof.

Consider the polynomial h​(t)ℎ𝑡h(t) given in (7.5). It suffices to find infinitely many primes p𝑝p, such that (h​(p−j)p)=1ℎ𝑝𝑗𝑝1\big{(}\tfrac{h(p-j)}{p}\big{)}=1, for a given j𝑗j. Consider first the case j=2𝑗2j=2. We look for prime numbers p𝑝p such that

(h​(p−2)p)=(−1p)​(5p)​(11p)=1.ℎ𝑝2𝑝1𝑝5𝑝11𝑝1\left(\tfrac{h(p-2)}{p}\right)=\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{11}{p}\right)=1.

We have (−1p)=(−1)p−121𝑝superscript1𝑝12\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)=(-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}} and (5p)=(−1)⌊p−12⌋5𝑝superscript1𝑝12\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)=(-1)^{\lfloor\frac{p-1}{2}\rfloor}. Hence, (−1p)=11𝑝1\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)=1 if p≡1𝑝1p\equiv 1 mod 444, (−1p)=−11𝑝1\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)=-1 if p≡3𝑝3p\equiv 3 mod 444, (5p)=15𝑝1\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)=1 if p≡±1𝑝plus-or-minus1p\equiv\pm 1 mod 555 and (5p)=−15𝑝1\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)=-1 if p≡±2𝑝plus-or-minus2p\equiv\pm 2 mod 555. As a first step, we find p𝑝p’s satisfying (−1p)​(5p)=11𝑝5𝑝1\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)=1. The values (−1p)=(5p)=11𝑝5𝑝1\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)=\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)=1 are obtained by taking p=20​k+1𝑝20𝑘1p=20k+1 or p=20​k+9𝑝20𝑘9p=20k+9 with k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}, while (−1p)=(5p)=−11𝑝5𝑝1\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)=\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)=-1 are obtained with p=20​k+3𝑝20𝑘3p=20k+3 or p=20​k+7𝑝20𝑘7p=20k+7 with k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}. Now, take p=(20⋅11)​k+j𝑝⋅2011𝑘𝑗p=(20\cdot 11)k+j with j=1,3,7𝑗137j=1,3,7 or 999 and k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}. By the quadratic reciprocity law, we have

(7.9) (11p)=(−1)(11−1)2​(p−1)2​((20⋅11)​k+111)=(111)=111𝑝superscript11112𝑝12⋅2011𝑘1111111\left(\tfrac{11}{p}\right)=(-1)^{\frac{(11-1)}{2}\frac{(p-1)}{2}}\left(\tfrac{(20\cdot 11)k+1}{11}\right)=\left(\tfrac{1}{11}\right)=1

for j=1,9𝑗19j=1,9. Similarly, we can do the same considering the cases of different parity in the symbols (−1p)1𝑝\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right) and (5p)5𝑝\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right). The pattern (−1p)=−11𝑝1\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)=-1 and (5p)=15𝑝1\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)=1 holds for p=20​k+11𝑝20𝑘11p=20k+11 or 20​k+1920𝑘1920k+19, k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}. By quadratic reciprocity, (7.9) above is also true for these values of p𝑝p (however, the pattern (−1p)=11𝑝1\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)=1, (5p)=−15𝑝1\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)=-1 does not lead to a solution of (7.9)).

That is, for every prime number of the form p=220​k+j𝑝220𝑘𝑗p=220k+j, with j=1,9,11,19𝑗191119j=1,9,11,19 and k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}, we have that (h​(p−2)p)=1ℎ𝑝2𝑝1\left(\tfrac{h(p-2)}{p}\right)=1. Proceeding similarly as before, from the expressions in (LABEL:bunch_of_legendres) one can prove similar results for R={p−j}𝑅𝑝𝑗R=\{p-j\} with 3≤j≤73𝑗73\leq j\leq 7 and we leave it to the reader. By Dirichlet’s theorem on arithmetic progressions, there are infinitely many prime numbers p𝑝p of the form 220​k+1220𝑘1220k+1, 220​k+9220𝑘9220k+9, 220​k+11220𝑘11220k+11 and p=220​k+19𝑝220𝑘19p=220k+19 with k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}, and thus the result follows. ∎

Notice that by using the same method as above, one can obtain asymptotically good sequences of 666-block transitive codes over 𝔽pssubscript𝔽superscript𝑝𝑠\mathbb{F}_{p^{s}} for every s≥1𝑠1s\geq 1 odd, by considering any two of the expressions in (LABEL:bunch_of_legendres) simultaneously. But now, since u=3𝑢3u=3, we have to take m=11𝑚11m=11 (by (6.3)) and hence we have to consider the polynomial h​(t)ℎ𝑡h(t) in (7.5) with n=6𝑛6n=6, that is (7.6) with 2≤k≤62𝑘62\leq k\leq 6. In other words,

(h6​(p−j)ps)=(1−jp)​∏k=26(j+kp)​(kp)​(k​j+1p)=(1−jp)​(h5​(p−j)ps)​(j+6p)​(6p)​(6​j+1p).subscriptℎ6𝑝𝑗superscript𝑝𝑠1𝑗𝑝superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘26𝑗𝑘𝑝𝑘𝑝𝑘𝑗1𝑝1𝑗𝑝subscriptℎ5𝑝𝑗superscript𝑝𝑠𝑗6𝑝6𝑝6𝑗1𝑝\left(\tfrac{h_{6}(p-j)}{p^{s}}\right)=\left(\tfrac{1-j}{p}\right)\prod_{k=2}^{6}\left(\tfrac{j+k}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{k}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{kj+1}{p}\right)=\left(\tfrac{1-j}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{h_{5}(p-j)}{p^{s}}\right)\left(\tfrac{j+6}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{6}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{6j+1}{p}\right).

So, for instance for j=2,3𝑗23j=2,3, by (7.7), we have

(h6​(p−2)ps)=(−1p)​(5p)​(11p)​(8p)​(6p)​(13p)=(−1p)​(3p)​(5p)​(11p)​(13p),subscriptℎ6𝑝2superscript𝑝𝑠1𝑝5𝑝11𝑝8𝑝6𝑝13𝑝1𝑝3𝑝5𝑝11𝑝13𝑝\displaystyle\left(\tfrac{h_{6}(p-2)}{p^{s}}\right)=\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{11}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{8}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{6}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{13}{p}\right)=\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{3}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{11}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{13}{p}\right),
(h​(p−3)ps)=(−1p)​(2p)​(5p)​(13p)​(9p)​(6p)​(19p)=(−1p)​(3p)​(5p)​(13p)​(19p).ℎ𝑝3superscript𝑝𝑠1𝑝2𝑝5𝑝13𝑝9𝑝6𝑝19𝑝1𝑝3𝑝5𝑝13𝑝19𝑝\displaystyle\left(\tfrac{h(p-3)}{p^{s}}\right)=\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{2}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{13}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{9}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{6}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{19}{p}\right)=\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{3}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{13}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{19}{p}\right).

It is known that (3p)=(−1)⌊p+16⌋3𝑝superscript1𝑝16\left(\tfrac{3}{p}\right)=(-1)^{\lfloor\tfrac{p+1}{6}\rfloor}, i.e. (3p)=13𝑝1\left(\tfrac{3}{p}\right)=1 if p≡±1𝑝plus-or-minus1p\equiv\pm 1 mod 121212 and p≡±5𝑝plus-or-minus5p\equiv\pm 5 mod 121212. Hence, for a prime of the form p=60​k+1𝑝60𝑘1p=60k+1 we have that (−1p)​(3p)​(5p)=11𝑝3𝑝5𝑝1\left(\tfrac{-1}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{3}{p}\right)\left(\tfrac{5}{p}\right)=1. So, consider a prime of the form

p=(11⋅13⋅19⋅60)​k+1=163021​k+1,k∈ℕ.formulae-sequence𝑝⋅11131960𝑘1163021𝑘1𝑘ℕp=(11\cdot 13\cdot 19\cdot 60)k+1=163021k+1,\qquad k\in\mathbb{N}.

By applying quadratic reciprocity again, we get (11p)=(13p)=(19p)=111𝑝13𝑝19𝑝1\left(\tfrac{11}{p}\right)=\left(\tfrac{13}{p}\right)=\left(\tfrac{19}{p}\right)=1. In this way, for primes of the form p=(11⋅13⋅19⋅60)​k+1𝑝⋅11131960𝑘1p=(11\cdot 13\cdot 19\cdot 60)k+1, k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}, the sets S={2,3,4,5,6}𝑆23456S=\{2,3,4,5,6\} and R={0,p−2,p−3}𝑅0𝑝2𝑝3R=\{0,p-2,p-3\} generates an asymptotically good sequence of 666-block transitive codes over 𝔽pssubscript𝔽superscript𝑝𝑠\mathbb{F}_{p^{s}} for every s𝑠s odd. In particular, for k=1𝑘1k=1 we get a good family of 666-block transitive codes over 𝔽163021subscript𝔽163021\mathbb{F}_{163021}.
